ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 12-78
   APPROVING, ADOPTING AND ENACTING THE CODIFIED ORDINANCES OF EVENDALE, OHIO,
1977; REPEALING ORDINANCES IN CONFLICT THEREWITH; AND PUBLISHING THE ENACTMENT
OF NEW MATTER.
   WHEREAS, the Council of the Village of Evendale, Ohio, has had the matter of
codification and general revision of the ordinances before it for some time,
and
   WHEREAS, it has heretofore entered into a contract with the Justinian
Publishing Company to prepare and publish such codification, and
   WHEREAS, the codification of such ordinances, together with the new matter
to be adopted, the matters to be amended, and those to be repealed are before
the Council,
   NOW THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE Council of the Village of Evendale,
Ohio:
   Section 1. The ordinances of the Village of Evendale, Ohio, of a general and
permanent nature, as revised, codified, arranged and consolidated into
component codes, titles, chapters and sections are hereby approved, adopted and
enacted as the Codified Ordinances of Evendale, Ohio, 1977.
   One book-form copy of the Codified Ordinances shall be certified as correct
by the Mayor and the Clerk, attached to this ordinance as a part hereof, and
filed with the permanent ordinance records of the Village of Evendale, Ohio.
   Section 2. All ordinances and resolutions or parts thereof which are in
conflict or inconsistent with any provision of the 1977 Codified Ordinances are
hereby repealed as of the effective date of this ordinance, except as follows:
   (a)   The enactment of the 1977 Codified Ordinances shall not be construed
to affect a right or liability accrued or incurred under any legislative
provision prior to the effective date of such enactment, or an action or
proceeding for the enforcement of such right or liability.  Such enactment
shall not be construed to relieve any person from punishment for an act
committed in violation of any such legislative provision, nor to affect an
indictment or prosecution therefor.  For such purposes, any legislative
provision shall continue in full force notwithstanding its repeal for the
purpose of revision and recodification.
   (b)   The repeal provided above shall not affect:
      (1)   The grant or creation of a franchise, license, right, easement or
privilege.
      (2)   The purchase, sale, lease or transfer of property.
      (3)   The appropriation or expenditure of money or promise or guarantee
of payment.
      (4)   The assumption of any contract or obligation.
      (5)   The issuance and delivery of any bonds, obligations or other
instruments of indebtedness.
      (6)   The levy or imposition of taxes, assessments or charges.
      (7)   The establishment, naming, vacating or grade level of any street or
public way.
      (8)   The dedication of property or plat approval.
      (9)   The annexation or detachment of territory.
      (10)  Any legislation enacted subsequent to October 7, 1977.
   Section 3. A section or subsection of the Codified Ordinances without a
legislative history at the end thereof is or contains new matter ordained by
this Adopting Ordinance.
   Section 4. Pursuant to Section 222.01(c) of the Codified Ordinances, the
Village Clerk shall cause a notice of the enactment of this ordinance,
containing the title of this ordinance and a summary of the new matters covered
by it, to be published once in a newspaper printed in Hamilton County and of
general circulation in the Village.
   Section 5. This ordinance shall take effect and be in force from and after
the earliest period allowed by law.
ATTEST:                              PASSED
/s/ Lucille V. Bossert                     /s/ William E. Trapp, Jr.
Village Clerk                           Mayor

ORDINANCE NO. 52-83
   APPROVING THE EDITING AND INCLUSION OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES AS PARTS OF THE
VARIOUS COMPONENT CODES OF THE CODIFIED ORDINANCES; PROVIDING FOR THE ADOPTION

general updating and revision of the Codified Ordinances of the Village before
it for some time, and
   WHEREAS, it has heretofore entered into a contract with The Justinian
Publishing Company to prepare and publish such updating and revision, and

passed by Council since the date of the last updating and revision of the
Codified Ordinances and have been included in the Codified Ordinances of the

SECTION 3:  Pursuant to Section 222.01(c) of the Codified Ordinances, the
Village Clerk shall cause a notice of the enactment of this ordinance,
containing the title of this ordinance and a summary of the new matters covered
by it, to be published once in a newspaper printed in Hamilton County of
general circulation in the Village.
SECTION 4:  All ordinances and resolutions or parts thereof which are in
conflict or inconsistent with any provision of the new matter adopted in
Section 2 of this ordinance are hereby repealed as of the effective date of
this ordinance except as follows:
      (a)   The enactment of such sections and subsections shall not be
construed to affect a right or liability accrued or incurred under any
legislative provision prior to the effective date of such enactment, or an
action or proceeding for the enforcement of such right or liability.  Such
enactment shall not be construed to relieve any person from punishment for an
act committed in violation of any such legislative provision, nor to affect an
indictment or prosecution therefor.  For such purposes, any such legislative
provision shall continue in full force notwithstanding its repeal for the
purpose of revision and recodification.
      (b)   The repeal provided above shall not affect any legislation enacted
subsequent to June 1, 1983.
SECTION 5:  This ordinance is hereby declared to be an emergency measure
necessary for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health, safety
and welfare, the reason for the emergency being that it is necessary to have an
up to date Code of the Village's laws, one which is consistent with State law
in areas where conformity is required by the Ohio Constitution, with which to
administer the affairs of the Village and ensure law and order, where- fore
this ordinance shall take effect and be in force immediately from and upon
passage.
                                    Passed unanimously, Aug. 4, 1983
                                    William E. Trapp, Jr.

in areas where conformity is required by the Ohio Constitution, with which to
administer the affairs of the Village and ensure law and order, wherefore this
ordinance shall take effect and be in force immediately from and upon passage.

ORDINANCE NO. 62-88
APPROVING THE EDITING AND INCLUSION OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES AS PARTS OF THE

ORDINANCE NO. 90-43

OF NEW MATTER IN THE UPDATED AND REVISED CODIFIED ORDINANCES; REPEALING
ORDINANCES IN CONFLICT THEREWITH; AND DECLARING AN EMERGENCY
WHEREAS, the Council of the Village of Evendale, Ohio has the matter of

Publishing Corporation to prepare and publish such updating and revision, and

by Council since the date of the last updating and revision of the codified

and
WHEREAS, certain changes were made in the Codified Ordinances to bring Village
law into conformity with state law,
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE VILLAGE OF EVENDALE, OHIO:
SECTION 1:  The editing, arrangement, and numbering or renumbering of the
following ordinances and parts of ordinances are hereby approved as parts of
the various component codes of the Codified Ordinances of the Village, so as to
conform to the classification and numbering system of the Codified Ordinances:

SECTION  2:  The following sections and subsections of the Codified Ordinances
are new matter in the Codified Ordinances, and are hereby approved, adopted,
and enacted:
402.34, 404.01, 404.05, 414.01, 414.02, 416.01, 416.06, 434.03, 434.08, 436.01,
436.02, 436.03, 436.04, 436.06, 436.06, 436.07, 436.12, 436.13, 438.22, 440.02,

636.02, 672.12, 698.06
SECTION 3:  Pursuant to Section 222.01 (c) of the Codified Ordinances, the
Village Clerk shall cause a notice of the enactment of this ordinance,
containing the title of this ordinance and a summary of the matters covered by
it, to be published once in a newspaper printed in Hamilton County of general
circulation in the Village.
SECTION 4:  All ordinances and resolutions or parts thereof which are in
conflict or inconsistent with any provision of the new matter adopted in
Section 2 of this ordinance are hereby repealed as of the effective date of
this ordinance except as follows:
(a)  The enactment of such sections and subsections shall not be construed to
affect a right or liability accrued or incurred under any legislative provision
prior to the effective date of such enactment, or an action or proceeding for
the enforcement of such right or liability.  Such enactment shall not be
construed to relieve any person from punishment for an act committed in
violation of any such legislative provision, nor to affect an indictment or
prosecution therefor.  For such purposes, any such legislative provision shall
continue in full force notwithstanding its repeal for the purpose of revision
and recodification.
(b)  The repeal provided above shall not affect any legislation enacted
subsequent to November 3, 1989.
SECTION  5:  This ordinance is hereby declared to be an emergency measure
necessary for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health, safety,
and welfare, the reason for the emergency being that it is necessary to have an
up-to-date Code of the Village's laws, one which is consistent with state law
in areas where conformity is required by the Ohio Constitution, and which to
administer the affairs of the Village and ensure law and order; wherefore this
ordinance shall take effect and be in force immediately from and upon passage.
                                       Adopted May 3, 1990

ORDINANCE NO. 96-19
   AN ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF ORDINANCES OF
THE VILLAGE OF EVENDALE, STATE OF OHIO AND DECLARING AN EMERGENCY
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio has
completed the September, 1995 Supplement (through Ordinance No. 95-96 and
Resolution No. 95-12) to the Code of Ordinances of the Village of Evendale,
which supplement contains all ordinances of a general nature enacted since the
prior supplement to the Code of Ordinances of this municipality; and,
WHEREAS, said American Legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the
revision or addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are
based on or make references to sections of the State of Ohio Code; and,
WHEREAS, it is the intent of Council to accept these updated sections in
accordance with the changes of the law of the State of Ohio;
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE VILLAGE OF EVENDALE, STATE
OF OHIO five members concurring that:
SECTION 1: That the September, 1995 Supplement (through Ordinance No. 95-96 and
Resolution No. 95-12) to the Code of Ordinances of the Village of Evendale,
State of Ohio as submitted by American Legal Publishing Corporation of
Cincinnati, and as attached hereto, be and the same is hereby adopted by
reference as if set out in its entirety.
SECTION 2:  This ordinance is declared to be an emergency by a concurrence of
five members of Council being necessary to preserve the public peace, order,
safety, health or welfare of the Village of Evendale or to provide for the
daily operation of a department or office of the Village  of Evendale.  It is
necessary that this measure be put into immediate effect because the public
welfare requires that an updated codification of ordinances be adopted. This
ordinance shall be effective upon passage.

ORDINANCE 04 56
ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING AN UPDATED CODE OF ORDINANCES OF THE VILLAGE OF
EVENDALE AND DECLARING AN EMERGENCY
WHEREAS, the American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio has
prepared a complete update to the Code of Ordinances of the Village of
Evendale, which contains all of the ordinances of a general and permanent
nature enacted, adopted and in effect in the Village of Evendale through May
13, 2004; and
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the revision or
addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are based on or
make reference to the Ohio Revised Code; and
WHEREAS, the update contains all local legislation through Ordinance No. 04 35,
adopted 5/13/04 and applicable state legislation current through 3/29/04; now,
therefore,
BE IT THEREFORE ORDAINED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE VILLAGE OF EVENDALE, STATE OF
OHIO, six members concurring, that:
SECTION 1: The complete update to the Code of Ordinances of the Village of
Evendale, State of Ohio, as submitted by American Legal Publishing Corporation
of Cincinnati, and as is attached hereto, be and the same is hereby adopted by
reference as if set out in its entirety herein.
SECTION 2: This Code of Ordinances shall be deemed published as of the day of
the adoption of this ordinance and the Clerk of the Village of Evendale is
hereby authorized and ordered to insert such supplement into the Code of
Ordinances kept on file in the Office of the Clerk.
SECTION 3: This ordinance is declared to be an emergency measure by a
concurrence of six members of Council, being necessary to preserve the public
peace, order, safety, health and welfare of the Village of Evendale, and to
provide for the daily operations of a department or office of the Village of
Evendale. It is necessary that this measure be put into immediate effect in
order to update the Code of Ordinances with recently adopted ordinances to
conform with recently adopted local and state legislation, to ensure that the
public officials in the Village of Evendale, as well as those citizens who need
to refer to it, have ready access to current laws effecting citizens and
businesses in the Village of Evendale. Therefore, this ordinance shall take
effect immediately.
               Approved August 12, 2004
               Don J. Apking    /s/

ORDINANCE 07-30
ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF ORDINANCES FOR THE
VILLAGE OF EVENDALE, OHIO AND DECLARING AN EMERGENCY
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio has
completed the July 2004 through July 2007 Supplement to the Code of Ordinances
of the Village of Evendale, Ohio, which supplement contains all of the
ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted since the prior 2004
Supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the Village of Evendale; and
WHEREAS, American Legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the revision or
addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are based on or
make reference to the Ohio Revised Code; and
WHEREAS, it is the intent of Village Council to accept these updated sections
in accordance with and in order to incorporate by reference these changes of
the law of the State of Ohio; now,
BE IT THEREFORE ORDAINED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE VILLAGE OF EVENDALE, STATE OF
OHIO, six members concurring, that:
SECTION 1: That the July 2004 through January 2007 Supplement to the Code of
Ordinances of the Village of Evendale, State of Ohio, as submitted by American
Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio, as attached hereto, be and
the same is hereby adopted by reference as if set out in its entirety.
SECTION 2: Such Supplement shall be deemed published as of the day of its
adoption and approval by the Council of the Village of Evendale, Ohio, and the
Clerk is hereby authorized and ordered to insert such Supplement into the copy
of the Code of Ordinances kept on file in the Office of the Clerk.
SECTION 3: By concurrence of six members of the Village Council this ordinance
is declared to be an emergency measure necessary to preserve the health, safety
and general welfare of the Village of Evendale or to provide for the daily
operation of a department or office of the Village of Evendale. It is necessary
that this matter be put into immediate effect to ensure that Evendale’s Code of
Ordinances is up-to-date and the Village is in the best position to be able to
enforce its Code. Therefore, this ordinance shall become effective upon its

ORDINANCE #10-38
VILLAGE OF EVENDALE, OHIO
   ORDINANCE ENACTING AND ADOPTING A SUPPLEMENT TO THE CODE OF ORDINANCES OF
THE VILLAGE OF EVENDALE, OHIO AND DECLARING AN EMERGENCY.
WHEREAS,   American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio, has
completed an update of the Village's Codified Ordinances through the end of
2009, which supplement contains all of the ordinances of a general and
permanent nature enacted since the prior 2004 Supplement to the Code of
Ordinances of the Village of Evendale; and
WHEREAS,   American Legal Publishing Corporation has recommended the revision
or addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are based on or
make reference to the Ohio Revised Code; and
WHEREAS,   It is the intent of the Council of the Village of Evendale to accept
these updated sections in accordance with and in order to incorporate by
reference these changes of the law of the State of Ohio; and
WHEREAS,   As a part of the update of the Code of Ordinances of the Village of
Evendale prepared by American Legal Publishing Corporation, a Cincinnati
company, a series of necessary amendments were noted; and
WHEREAS,   These amendment are necessary in order to conform the Evendale Code
to certain provisions of the Ohio Revised Code; now,
BE IT THEREFORE ORDAINED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE VILLAGE OF EVENDALE, STATE OF
OHIO,        members concurring, that:
SECTION 1:  The 2009 Supplement to the Codified Ordinances of the Village of
Evendale contains amendments and supplements to the Evendale Code of Ordinances
adopted since the July 2007 Supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the Village
of Evendale prepared by American Legal Publishing Corporation through December
10, 2009, as submitted by American Legal Publishing Corporation of Cincinnati,
Ohio, as attached hereto, be and the same as hereby adopted by reference with
the amendments set forth in Section 3 below as if set out in its entirety
herein.
SECTION 2:  Such supplement shall be deemed published as of the day of its
adoption and approval by the Council of the Village of Evendale, Ohio, and the
Clerk is hereby authorized and ordered to insert such supplement into the Code
of Ordinances kept on file in the Office of the Village Clerk.
SECTION 3:  The following amendments to the 2009 Supplement are hereby adopted
and shall become, along with the 2009 Supplement, a part of the Codified
Ordinances of the Village of Evendale.
SUBSECTION A.  Section 436.01, License Required, of the Codified Ordinances of
the Village of Evendale, is hereby amended by repealing Subparagraphs (e) and
(g) and amending current Subparagraph (f) to be renumbered as (e) and amended
to read as follows:
      (e)   Any offender, convicted of or who has pleaded guilty to one or more
offenses of operating a motor vehicle without a valid license or violations of
a substantially equivalent municipal ordinance within the past three years, and
if the offender's license was expired for more than six months at the time of
the offense, the Mayor's Court shall impose, pursuant to the requirements of
the Ohio Revised Code, a Class 7 (a definite period not to exceed one year)
suspension of the offender's license, permit or privilege. The Court may not
impose a license suspension for a first violation or operating a motor vehicle
without a valid license or if more than three years have passed since the
offender's last violation of operating a motor vehicle without a valid license.
SUBSECTION B.  Section 438.22, Sign or Poster Upon Windshield; Windshield
Wiper, Subparagraph (b) shall be amended to read as follows:
      (b)   No person shall drive any motor vehicle, other than a bus, with any
sign, poster or non-transparent material upon the front windshield, side wings,
side or rear windows of such vehicle, other than a certificate or other paper
required to be displayed by law, except that there may be in the lower left-
hand or right-hand corner of the windshield a sign, poster or decal not to
exceed four inches in height by six inches in width, or a student driver
sticker or banner issued and displayed in compliance with Ohio R.C. 4507.232.
No sign, poster or decal may be displayed in the front window in such a manner
as to conceal the vehicle identification number for the motor vehicle when, in
accordance with federal law, that number is located inside the vehicle
passenger compartment and so placed as to be readable through the vehicle
glazing without moving any part of the vehicle.
SUBSECTION C.  Section 438.31, Occupant Restraining Device Required, Subsection
(g), Penalty, shall be amended to read as follows:
      (g)   Penalty.
         (1)   Whoever violates division (b)(1) of this section shall be fined
Thirty Dollars ($30.00).
         (2)   Whoever violates division (b)(2) of this section shall be
subject to the penalty set forth in Section 408.02.
         (3)   Whoever violates division (b)(3) of this section shall be fined
Twenty Dollars ($20.00).
         (4)   Except as otherwise provided in this division, whoever violates
division (b)(4) of this section is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. If the
offender previously has been convicted of or pleaded guilty to a violation of
division (b)(4) of this section, whoever violates division (b)(4) of this
section is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree.
SUBSECTION D.  Section 438.32, Use of Tinted Glass or Other Vision Obstructing
Materials Restricted on the Codified Ordinances of the Village of Evendale,
Subsection (f) is hereby amended to read as follows:
      (f)   With regard to any side windows behind a driver's seat, or any rear
window other than any window on an emergency door, this section does not apply
to any school bus used to transport a child with disabilities pursuant to a
special education program under Ohio R.C. Chapter 3323, whom it is impossible
or impractical to transport by regular school bus in the course of regular
route transportation provided by a school district. As used in this division,
"child with disabilities" and "special education program" have the same
meanings as in Ohio R.C. 3323.01.
SUBSECTION E.  Section 698.02, Penalties for Misdemeanor of the Codified
Ordinances of the Village of Evendale, is hereby amended to provide in
Subsection 698.02(b)(5), the deletion of the reference to Ohio R.C. 2941.1414
and replacing it with Ohio R.C. 2941.1416.  All other provisions in Section
698.02 of the Codified Ordinances of the Village of Evendale shall remain
unchanged.
SECTION 4:  This ordinance is declared to be an emergency measure by a
concurrence of        members of Council.  It being necessary to preserve the
public peace, order, safety, health or welfare of the Village of Evendale, or
to provide for the daily operation of a department or office of the Village of
Evendale.  It is necessary that this matter be put into immediate effect to
ensure that Evendale's Code of Ordinances is up-to-date and the Village is in
the best position to be able to enforce its Code. Therefore, this ordinance
shall become effective upon its passage.
                              Approved                                      
                                                                               
   
                                    Mayor
Attest:
                                                 
Village Clerk
Approved as to Form:
                                                 
Village Solicitor
1st Reading: 7/8/10
Rules Suspended:
2nd and 3rd Reading: 8/12/10
Emergency Section Agreed to:
Notice of publication:
ORDINANCE #12-39
VILLAGE OF EVENDALE, OHIO
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE 2012 S-4 SUPPLEMENT TO THE EVENDALE VILLAGE CODE OF
ORDINANCES INCLUDING ORDINANCES ADOPTED THROUGH ORDINANCE 11-44A PASSED ON
OCTOBER 11, 2011 AND STATE LEGISLATIO N ADOPTED THROUGH DECEMBER 31, 2011, AND
DECLARING AN EMERGENCY.
WHEREAS,   From time to time it is necessary to adopt and incorporate into the
Village of Evendale Code of Ordinances supplements to the Code incorporating
recently adopted ordinances, and statutes; and
WHEREAS,   American Legal Publishing publishes the Village of Evendale Code of
Ordinances and has prepared and recommended such a supplement to be
incorporated into the Code of Ordinances;
NOW THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the Council of the Village of Evendale, State
of Ohio, six members concurring, that:

containing local legislation adopted through Ordinance 11-44A passed on October
11, 2011 and state legislation current through December 31, 2011 as prepared by
American Legal Publishing Corporation is hereby adopted and incorporated into
the Village of Evendale Code of Ordinances. A complete text of said Supplement
is on file with the Clerk of Council and available for public inspection or
purchase. The Clerk is instructed to insert such a supplement into the official
copy of the Evendale Code of Ordinances maintained in the village offices.

concurrence of six members of Council, it being necessary to preserve the
public health, safety, and general welfare of the Village of Evendale, or to
provide for the daily operations of a department or office of the Village of
Evendale. The reason for said emergency is the necessity to provide for an
updated Code of Ordinances at the earliest possible date. Therefore, this
Ordinance shall become effective immediately.

PRELIMINARY UNIT
   EXPLANATION OF TABLES OF SPECIAL ORDINANCES
      The Codified Ordinances of Evendale cover all ordinances of a general and
permanent nature.  The provisions of such general and permanent ordinances are
set forth in full in the Codified Ordinances.
      References must be made frequently to many special ordinances -
particularly those related to property, such as dedications, vacating of
property, easements, purchase, sale, etc.  In the following Tables A through I,
all such ordinances are listed.  These tables list ordinances chronologically
by subject, and include both a citation and brief description of each
ordinance.
TABLE OF SPECIAL ORDINANCES OF EVENDALE
   
Table A - Franchises
   
Table B - Easements
   
Table C - Vacating of Streets and Alleys
   
Table D - Dedication and Plat Approval
   
Table E - Acquisition and Disposal of Real Property
   
Table F - Lease of Real Property
   
Table G - Street Grade Levels and Change of Street Name
   
Table H - Annexation and Detachment of Territory
   
Table I - Zoning Map Changes
   
Table J - Intergovernmental Agreements
TABLE A - FRANCHISES
 
Ord. No. Date Passed Description
                   To the Cincinnati Gas & Electric Co., the right to occupy
22-52     10-7-52  streets, etc., for the purpose of laying mains, etc., for
                   natural gas service for 25 yrs.
                   To the Cincinnati Gas & Electric Co., the right to occupy
31-53     11-5-53  the streets, etc., with poles, etc., for electrical service
                   for 25 yrs.
32-53     11-5-53  Regulating rates and charges for electricity furnished by
                   the Cincinnati Gas & Electric Co.
33-53     11-5-53  Contract with the Cincinnati Gas & Electric Co. for street
                   lighting for 5 yrs.

REFERENCES TO THE OHIO REVISED CODE
EDITOR'S NOTE: This table lists those Ohio Revised Code sections which have
been substantially duplicated by corresponding Code of Ordinance sections.  All
legislative history references to “(ORC xx.xx)” which appear at the end of
sections (or divisions of sections) in the Village's Code of Ordinances have
been listed here.  Example: to determine which section of the Code of
Ordinances is based on ORC 4511.19, scan down this table to the citation for
“4511.19” and examine the entry across from it: in this case, the corresponding
Code of Ordinances section is 434.01, which means that 434.01 (or a part
thereof) is based directly on ORC 4511.19.

CHARTER
EDITOR'S NOTE: The original Evendale Charter was adopted on April 10, 1952, and
amended on November 8, 1960, November 3, 1964, November 7, 1967, May 5, 1970,
May 4, 1971, May 2, 1972, November 7, 1972 and November 6, 1973. On June 8,
1976, the voters approved an Amended Charter, the same having been previously
recommended by the Charter Review Committee. This Amended Charter is set forth
below. Dates appearing in parentheses at the end of section headings indicate
that the section was subsequently amended, enacted or repealed on the date
given.
ARTICLE I
FORM OF GOVERNMENT AND POWERS
SECTION 1. GENERAL POWERS.
   The people of the Village of Evendale, within its territorial limits as they
are now or as they may be hereafter established, shall be a body politic and
corporate by the name "The Village of Evendale," and as such shall have
perpetual succession. The Village shall have home rule and under this Charter
shall possess all powers of local self-government and such local police,
sanitary and similar powers as are granted by the Constitution of Ohio, and all
other powers granted to municipalities by law.  No reference in this Charter to
any particular power shall be deemed to be exclusive. If the manner of
exercising any power be not prescribed in this Charter, it shall be exercised
in the manner prescribed by ordinance, or in the manner prescribed by general
law in any case wherein it is not within the power of the Village to alter or
modify such manner or wherein it has not been prescribed by ordinance.
SECTION 2. FORM OF GOVERNMENT.
   The government of the Village of Evendale shall be the Mayor-Council type
with the powers of the Mayor and Council to be as defined in this Charter.
SECTION 3.  POWERS OF MAYOR.
   The Mayor shall be the chief executive officer and chief conservator of the
peace within the Village. The Mayor shall see that the ordinances of the
Village and the laws of the State are enforced, and that all contracts to which
the Village is a party are carried out.  The Mayor shall have all the general
and judicial powers vested by the laws of the State and shall perform all the
duties prescribed by the ordinances of the Village. The Mayor shall be
recognized as the official and ceremonial head of the Village and by the
Governor for military purposes, and by the courts for the purpose of serving
civil process.
SECTION 4.  POWERS OF COUNCIL.
   All legislative powers of the Village, except the powers of the initiative
and referendum reserved to the electors in this Charter, shall be vested in a
Council which shall consist of six members.
SECTION 5.  INITIATIVE AND REFERENDUM.
   The people of the Village of Evendale hereby reserve to themselves the
legislative powers of the initiative and referendum.  Such powers shall be
exercised in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution of Ohio and,
except as is otherwise provided in this section, in accordance with general
law.  No measure shall be exempt from the referendum by reason of having been
passed or adopted as an emergency measure, but the filing of a referendum
petition against an emergency measure shall neither prevent its going into
effect nor suspend its continuing in force and effect, unless and until it
shall be disapproved by a majority of those voting on it at the referendum
election.
SECTION 6.  RECALL.
   Any elective officer of this Municipal Government may be removed from such
office, and the successor thereto elected, by the qualified electors of the
Municipality in the same manner and pursuant to the requirements and with the
effect prescribed by Ohio R.C. 705.92 as it provides on the date of adoption of
this Charter, as though the terms of said Section were fully herein set forth,
except that the question of any such removal of any such officer may be
submitted to such electors after, but only after, such officer has been in
office-for six months of the term thereof during which the officer is sought to
be recalled. The provisions for recall hereinabove in this Charter made shall
not be nullified or altered by any repeal or amendment of said Ohio R.C. 705.92
after such date of adoption of this Charter.
SECTION 7.  ANNUAL TOWN MEETING.
   A town meeting of the electors of the Village shall be held each year.  The
Council shall provide for such meeting, and shall cause at least ten days
public notice to be given thereof. The Village Clerk shall call the meeting to
order, and thereafter the meeting shall choose a moderator, who shall not hold
any office under the Village, and a secretary, and shall determine its own
rules. The members of the Council and the Mayor shall attend the town meeting
and shall describe and explain the services, operations, finances and affairs
of the Village for the current and ensuing years and shall answer questions
concerning the same. The town meeting may agree to a statement of the sense of
the electors participating therein on any subject, but such a statement shall
not bind any officer of the Village.
ARTICLE II
RULES OF COUNCIL
SECTION 1.  MEETINGS OF COUNCIL.
   The members of the Council elected at any general Municipal election shall
meet with the other members of Council at 8:00 p.m. on the first day of
December next thereafter (or on the next day if the first be a Sunday), at the
usual meeting place of the Council, and shall then qualify by taking and
subscribing to an oath or affirmation of office, and shall enter upon their
duties. The Council shall hold not fewer than twelve regular monthly meetings
each year, at such place and at such times as shall be determined in its rules
or by ordinance. Special meetings may be called by the Mayor or by any three
members of the Council, by written notice served personally upon each member or
left at their usual place of residence at least twelve hours in advance.  All
meetings of the Council and of its committees shall be open to the public, in
accordance with general law.
SECTION 2.  RULES OF ORDER.
   The Council shall adopt its own rules of order and business.  The Mayor
shall preside at all meetings of Council, but shall have no vote therein except
in the case of a three to three tie vote of Council wherein the Mayor shall be
considered a member of Council for the purpose of casting the deciding vote.
The Mayor shall have the right to introduce ordinances and resolutions and to
take part in the discussion of all matters coming before Council.
SECTION 3.  QUORUM AND VOTING.
   Four members of the Council shall be a quorum to do business, but a smaller
number may adjourn from time to time and compel the attendance of absent
members. Every ordinance, and every resolution having any force or effect of
law, shall be read on three separate days before being passed, unless this
requirement be suspended by the concurrence of at least five members of the
Council. The final reading shall be in full unless a written or printed copy of
such ordinance or resolution shall have been furnished to each member of the
Council at least twenty-four hours before the vote is taken on passage or
adoption. The affirmative votes of at least four members of the Council shall
be necessary for the passage or adoption of any measure, or for the
affirmation, or removal of any appointed officer.  Every vote upon any
ordinance or upon any resolution having any force or effect of law, and upon
the affirmation or removal of any appointed officer, and every other vote as to
which any member shall demand the yeas and nays, shall be taken upon a roll
call and entered upon the journal.
SECTION 4.  TIME OF TAKING EFFECT OF ORDINANCES.
   Emergency measures, and measures to which the referendum is not applicable,
shall take effect and be in force from and after their passage or adoption, or
at such later times as shall be provided by their terms.  Every other measure
shall take effect and be in force thirty days after its passage or adoption,
unless suspended by the filing of a referendum petition.
SECTION 5.  EMERGENCY MEASURES.
   An emergency measure is an ordinance, or resolution having the force or
effect of law, a separate section of which declares that it is necessary to put
such measure into immediate force and effect in order to preserve the public
peace, order, safety, health, or welfare of the Village, or to provide for the
usual daily operation of a department or office of the Village, and states
specifically the reason and nature of such necessity, and specifies the time
when such measure shall go into force and effect. No such emergency declaration
shall be included in any measure unless at least five members of the Council
agree thereto, on a separate roll call vote taken before the vote upon passage
or adoption and entered on the journal, and no measure including a declaration
of emergency shall be passed or adopted by the vote of fewer than five members
of the Council.
SECTION 6.  PUBLICATION.
   The Council shall provide by ordinance for the publication or posting of
ordinances and of resolutions having the force or effect of law, and may
provide in what cases such publication or posting by title shall be
sufficient.  Copies of all such measures shall be open to public inspection at
all reasonable hours at the office of the Village Clerk.  The Council may
provide written notification of public hearings in addition to newspaper
publications, by motion of Council, to electors not less than seven days prior
to the time of the public hearing.
ARTICLE III
ELECTED OFFICERS
SECTION 1.  NOMINATIONS AND ELECTIONS.
   All nominations and elections of elective officers of the Village shall be
nonpartisan, and no party designation shall be permitted on any nominating
petition or on any ballot for any Village office.  Any group of electors of the
Village, not fewer than fifteen in number, may by petition nominate a candidate
or candidates for the Council, but not more than six such candidates shall be
nominated upon any one petition.  No officers of the Village of Evendale, other
than members of the Council and the Mayor, shall be elected by popular vote.
Nominating petitions shall be filed not later than ninety days before a general
Municipal election.
SECTION 2.  CONDUCT OF ELECTIONS.
   All elections in and for the Village of Evendale shall be conducted by the
election authorities constituted by general law. Except as is otherwise
provided in this Charter, such elections shall be governed by the general
election laws of Ohio.
SECTION 3. THE MAYOR.
   The Mayor shall be elected from the Village at large at the general
Municipal elections in odd-numbered years for a term of four years commencing
on the first day of December next after being elected. The Mayor shall be an
elector of the Village and shall have resided in the Village two years prior to
being elected. No person shall serve in more than three successive terms as
Mayor, provided that each term shall consist of half or more of a regular term.
SECTION 4.  MEMBERS OF COUNCIL.
   Members of the Council shall be elected from the Village at large at the
general Municipal elections in odd-numbered years for terms of four years. Each
member of Council shall be an elector of the Village and shall have resided in
the Village two years next preceding his election. One half the seats on
Council shall be filled by election every two years.  Their regular terms shall
commence on the first day of December next after their election, and shall end
with the thirtieth day of November next after the election of their successors.
No person shall serve in more than three successive terms as a member of
Council, provided that each term shall consist of half or more of a regular
term.
SECTION 5.  VICE-MAYOR AND PRESIDENT PRO TEMPORE.
   The Council at the time of its organization each two years shall choose one
of its members to be Vice-Mayor.  The Vice-Mayor shall exercise the powers and
perform the duties of the Mayor during the temporary absence or disability of
the Mayor, and shall succeed to the office of Mayor in case of any vacancy
therein for a term which shall end on the first thirtieth day of November
occurring in any odd-numbered year, after such succession takes place.
   The Council at the time of its organization each two years shall choose
another of its members to be President Pro Tempore, and to exercise the powers
and duties of the Mayor during the temporary absence or disability of both the
Mayor and Vice-Mayor.  The President Pro Tempore shall succeed to the office of
Mayor in case of a vacancy therein which occurs after the Vice-Mayor has
succeeded to the office, and shall serve for a term which shall end on the
first thirtieth day of November occurring in an odd-numbered year after such
succession takes place.
   While so acting as Mayor during a temporary absence or disability, the Vice-
Mayor or the President Pro Tempore shall not cease to be a member of Council
nor lose the right to vote as a member of Council.
   In the event that either the Vice-Mayor or President Pro Tempore vacates his
seat on Council, the Council, after filling the vacancy, shall reorganize at
the next regular meeting.
SECTION 6.  VACATING THE SEAT OF ELECTED OFFICERS.
   The Council shall declare vacant the seat of any elected officer of the
Village who shall cease to be a resident or an elector of the Village, or who
shall hold any other elected public office or any other Village employment,
except that of unpaid member of any Village commission, board, or committee.
Also, the Council may vacate the seat of any elected officer of the Village
when such officer is found guilty of gross misconduct, malfeasance, misfeasance
or nonfeasance in or for disqualification for office or for the conviction
while in office of a crime involving moral turpitude, or for the violation of
the oath of office. Such vacating shall require the concurrence of five members
of Council and shall not take place unless and until said elected officer has
been notified in writing of the charge or until the elected officer and counsel
shall have been given an opportunity to be heard, present evidence, and examine
witnesses appearing in support of such charges.
(Amendment approved by the electorate 11-6-84; Amendment approved by the
electorate 11-8-16)
SECTION 7.  VACANCIES TO BE FILLED.
   Whenever one or two vacancies shall happen in the membership of Council, the
remaining members thereof shall by the concurrence of a majority choose a
qualified electro of the Village to fill such vacancy until such time as an
election may be had to fill such unexpired term. An election to fill such
unexpired term or terms shall be held at the next general municipal election
occurring more than one hundred twenty days after the vacancy on Council is
declared. If three or more vacancies shall happen in the membership of Council,
a special election shall be held to fill those seats for the remainder of the
unexpired terms.
(Amendment approved by the electorate 11-6-84; Amendment approved by the
electorate 11-8-16)
ARTICLE IV
APPOINTED OFFICERS
SECTION 1.  VILLAGE CLERK.
   The Mayor shall appoint, with the concurrence of Council, a Village Clerk
who shall be a resident of the Village and serve at the pleasure of the
Council. The Village Clerk shall attend all meetings of the Council and shall
keep its journal and other records, shall preserve all books and papers
pertaining to this office, and shall perform such other duties as the Council
shall prescribe, consistent with this Charter.
   The Mayor may appoint, with the concurrence of Council, a Village Fiscal and
Accounting Officer who need not be a resident of the Village and who shall
serve at the pleasure of the Council. The Village Fiscal and Accounting Officer
shall perform all fiscal and accounting functions for the Village.
   Where no Village Fiscal and Accounting Officer is appointed, the Village
Clerk shall be the fiscal and accounting officer of the Village.
(Amendment approved by the electorate 11-5-02)
SECTION 2.  VILLAGE TREASURER.
   The Mayor shall appoint, with the concurrence of Council, a Village
Treasurer who shall be a resident of the Village and serve at the pleasure of
the Council, and shall perform the duties of Village Treasurer under general
law.
SECTION 3.  LAW DIRECTOR.
   The Mayor shall appoint, with the concurrence of Council, a Village Law
Director to serve at the pleasure of Council. The Law Director shall be an
attorney-at-law admitted to practice in Ohio, shall be a resident of Hamilton
County, shall be the legal advisor of and attorney and counsel for the Village
and for all officers and departments thereof in all matters relating to their
official duties, and shall, upon request therefor, give legal opinions in
writing. Law Director shall represent the Village in all litigation to which it
may be a party, and shall prosecute for all offenses against the ordinances of
the Village and for offenses against the laws of Ohio except in cases where
Council by ordinance engages special counsel. Law Director shall be responsible
for the preparation of all contracts, bonds, and other instruments in writing
in which the Village if concerned, and shall endorse on each the approval of
the form and correctness thereof. Law Director shall perform all other duties
of a legal nature imposed by ordinance or resolution, or imposed upon the chief
legal officers of municipalities by general law which it is not competent for
the Village to modify or set aside. 
(Amendment adopted by the electorate 11-8-16)
SECTION 4.  DIRECTOR OF ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES.
   The Council shall by ordinance provide for and the Mayor may appoint with
the concurrence of Council, a Director of Administrative Services to assist the
Mayor in the performance of duties, but such appointment shall not relieve the
Mayor as the responsible executive officer of the Village. The Mayor, with
concurrence of Council, may delegate to the Director of Administrative Services
the authority to execute on behalf of the Mayor all documents necessary to
obtain goods and services not exceeding five thousand dollars ($5,000) for any
department or office of the Village.
(Amendment adopted by the electorate 11-5-02; Amendment adopted by the
electorate 11-8-16)
SECTION 5.  POLICE FORCE.
   The Council shall by ordinance provide for a Police Force adequate to the
needs of the Village, and shall determine the ranks and numbers of regular
members thereof, and may provide for auxiliary police.  The Mayor shall
appoint, with the concurrence of Council, the Chief of Police, who shall in all
cases be a member of the unclassified service.
SECTION 6. FIRE PROTECTION.
   The Council shall provide by ordinance for the protection of lives and
property within the Village from fire, either by the establishment of a Fire
Force or by contract, or by both. The Mayor shall appoint, with the concurrence
of Council, the Chief of the Fire Department, who shall in all cases be a
member of the unclassified service.
SECTION 7. OTHER APPOINTED OFFICERS.
   The Council shall provide by ordinance for other departments necessary for
the conduct of services to the Village and the Mayor shall appoint, with the
concurrence of Council, the heads of such departments, who shall serve at the
pleasure of Council.
ARTICLE V
FISCAL MATTERS
SECTION 1. APPROPRIATION ORDINANCE.
   On or before the first day of December in each year, the Mayor shall submit
to the Council an appropriation ordinance presenting a financial plan for
conducting the affairs of the Village during the next ensuing year. The Council
shall hold at least one public hearing upon such appropriation ordinance, on or
before the twenty-first day of such December.
SECTION 2. CONTRACTS FOR GOVERNMENTAL FUNCTIONS.
   The Council may authorize the contracting with the County of Hamilton or
with any city, village or township in Hamilton County for the performance of
any governmental function required by or capable of being furnished by the
Village. No such contract shall be entered into for a period longer than two
years unless the ordinance authorizing the same shall be passed by the votes of
at least five members of the Council.
SECTION 3. CONTRACTS FOR SERVICES AND MATERIALS.
   The Mayor, as Chief Executive Authority, with the approval of Council, may
make any contract, purchase supplies or materials, or provide labor for any
work under the supervision of Village officials involving not more than the
amount villages are permitted to expend under the Ohio Revised Code without
competitive bidding. When an expenditure, other than compensation to Village
employees, exceeds the amount villages are permitted to expend under the Ohio
Revised Code without competitve bidding, such expenditure shall first be
authorized and directed by ordinance of the Council. When so authorized and
directed the Mayor shall make a written contract with the lowest and best
bidder after advertisement for not less than two nor more than four consecutive
weeks in a newspaper of general circulation within the Village. Council may by
Ordinance, provide for participation in joint purchasing programs operated by
the State of Ohio or department thereof. However, no purchase from such joint
purchasing program in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000) may be made
unless the Ordinance authorizing same shall be passed by Council. 
Notwithstanding the foregoing language of this section, Council may, by
ordinance, without the necessity of competitive bidding, authorize and approve
a lease, contract or other agreement with or contribute to the Gorman Heritage
Farm Foundation, a charitable non-profit Ohio corporation which shall be
qualified as an IRC 501(c)(3) tax exempt entity, to operate, maintain and
manage some or all of the Gorman Heritage Farm and the programs associated with
it. 
(Amendment adopted by the electorate 11-7-89; 3-2-04; 11-2-04)
SECTION 4. TAX LIMITATIONS.
   No tax shall be levied in or for any year upon real or personal property
according to value in excess of the following limitations:
   a.   For the purposes of the Police Pension Fund or of the Firemen's Pension
Fund, at a rate sufficient to produce the amounts required for such purposes
but not in excess of the rates prescribed therefor by general law;
   b.   For all other current operating purposes, and for paying the principal
of and interest upon bonds and notes of the Village issued without the vote of
the people, except special assessments bonds and notes, at a rate not in
excess, for both such purposes together, of three-tenths of one percent upon
assessed values;
   c.   In addition to the foregoing limitations, taxes shall be levied for
paying the principal of and interest upon the bonds or notes of the Village
issued pursuant to the vote of the people, at a rate sufficient to produce the
amounts required for that purpose.
   This section is adopted pursuant to the authorization contained in Section 2
of Article XII of the Constitution of Ohio, and in Section 5625-14 of the
General Code of Ohio (Section 5705.18 of the Revised Code of Ohio) and the
limitations herein are in lieu of the constitutional and statutory limitation
of one percent, as that limitation would otherwise apply to the Village of
Evendale.
SECTION 5. EXTRA LEVIES AND BOND ISSUES.
   The Council may submit to the voters the question of authorizing the issuing
of bonds and the levy of taxes upon real and personal property according to
value in excess of the limitations prescribed in
Article V, Section 6, of this Charter. Such question shall be submitted under
the provisions of general law governing the submission of bond issues and tax
levies in excess of the constitutional limitation, except that no such
authorization for an extra levy for current operating expenses shall be for
more than two years, and except that when any such question is submitted sixty
percent of the votes cast on such question shall be sufficient to make such
authorization.
SECTION 6. LIMITATION OF ISSUANCE OF BONDS WITHOUT VOTE OF THE PEOPLE.
   Notwithstanding any provision of general law, the amount of bonds, except
special assessment bonds, issued by the Council without vote of the electors,
and payable from the proceeds of taxes upon real and personal property
according to value, shall never exceed Five Million Dollars ($5,000,000)
outstanding at any one time.
(Amended 11-1-81; Amendment adopted by the electorate 11-7-89; Amendment
adopted by the electorate 11-8-16)
SECTION 7. AUDITS.
   The Council may at any time cause an audit to be made of the accounts of
financial affairs of the Village or of any officer or department of the Village
for any period of time it may designate. Such audit shall be made by a
certified public accountant chosen for the purpose by the Council, that
otherwise employed by the Village, nor financially interested in any
transaction to be audited.
SECTION 8. SALARIES AND COMPENSATION.
   Each member of the Council shall be paid during his term as provided by
ordinance. A public hearing must be held not less than thirty days prior to the
passage of such ordinance. The salaries, fees and other compensations payable
to other officials and employees of the Village shall also be fixed by
ordinance. But no member of the Village Planning Commission shall be paid any
salary or compensation from the Village for service as such, except that
Council may provide by ordinance compensation to the Secretary of the Planning
Commission.
SECTION 9. HEALTH DISTRICT.
   (This section was repealed by vote of the electorate 11-7-89)
ARTICLE VI
PLANNING AND ZONING
SECTION 1. VILLAGE PLANNING COMMISSION.
   There shall be a Village Planning Commission which shall consist of five
members, each of whom shall be appointed by the Council. One member shall be a
member of the Council and shall serve during his term as such. At least two of
the remaining members shall be electors of the village, and none of such
remaining members shall hold any other office or employment under the Village.
The Council may appoint not more than two nonresidents of the Village as
members of the Village Planning Commission, provided that each of such
nonresident members shall be an owner, officer or employee of a business or
industry operating in Evendale.  The members of the Village Planning Commission
shall be appointed for regular terms of four years, so arranged that not more
than one regular term shall expire in any year. Each member appointed as a
nonresident shall serve during his regular term at the pleasure of the Council,
and shall cease to be a member upon ceasing to possess the qualifications
requisite for his appointment. A member appointed as an elector shall cease to
be a member upon ceasing to be an elector of the Village. Any vacancy which
shall happen in a regular term shall be filled for the unexpired portion of
such term.
SECTION 2. DUTIES OF PLANNING COMMISSION.
   The Village Planning Commission shall make and may from time to time amend
or modify a General Village Plan, a Zoning Plan and other plans for the
development of the Village, and shall be the Platting Commission of the
Village, all in accordance with law, and shall perform such other duties,
related to planning, zoning and platting, as shall be imposed upon it by
ordinance or resolution.
SECTION 3. COUNCIL ACTION ON PLANS, PLATS OR ZONING.
   No plan or amendment or modification thereof made or proposed by the Village
Planning Commission shall become effective unless and until the same shall be
reported to the Council and embodied in an ordinance. No plat approved by, nor
any dedication or gift of property recommended for acceptance by, the Village
Planning Commission shall be deemed to be accepted unless and until it shall be
done by ordinance. Every such ordinance which shall be amended in the Council
not in accordance with a recommendation of the Village Planning Commission, and
every other ordinance which would make, amend or modify any plan, or which
would approve any plat or accept any dedication or gift, unless the same were
previously acted upon by the Village Planning Commission, shall, before
passage, be referred to the Village Planning Commission for its recommendation
thereon. The Village Planning Commission shall report its recommendation
thereon to the Council not later than the next regular meeting of the Council
which occurs not sooner than fourteen days after such reference. If the
Commission shall fail to make any report thereon by such time it shall be
deemed to have approved the proposed ordinance.
   The affirmative votes of five members of the Council shall be necessary to
pass any ordinance contemplated in this section if such ordinance shall contain
anything contrary to the recommendation of the Village Planning Commission.
SECTION 4.  ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS.
   Council shall by ordinance provide a Zoning Board of Appeals separate from
the Planning Commission.
ARTICLE VII
REVIEW OF AND AMENDMENTS TO CHARTER
SECTION 1.  REVIEW COMMITTEE.
   A committee to review the Charter and incorporate amendments may be
appointed at the pleasure of the Mayor at any time and shall report
recommendations to the Mayor within six months time.
SECTION 2.  CHARTER REVIEW COMMITTEE.
   In addition to the methods of amending this Charter provided for in
Article VII, Section 3, which conforms to the Ohio Constitution Article XVIII,
Section 9, no less than once every ten years the Mayor shall appoint a
committee to review this Charter. The committee shall be composed of four
electors of the Village of Evendale and one member of the Evendale Village
Council. The committee shall, within 90 days of its appointment, report its
results and recommendations to Village Council, which shall consider such
report and determine what, if any, proposed amendments to this Charter to
submit to the voter as provided for in
Article VII, Section 3.
(Amendment adopted by the electorate 11-8-16)
SECTION 3.  AMENDMENTS TO CHARTER.
   This Charter is intended to be flexible and to be changed to meet changing
conditions as the Village develops, in order that the best interests of those
who live and work here may continue to be served. Amendments may be submitted
to the electors by a two-thirds vote of Council, and shall be submitted upon
petition signed by ten percent of the electors. Copies of proposed amendments
shall be mailed to the electors not less than thirty days prior to the date of
an election at which such amendments are to be voted on. If any such amendment
is approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon, it shall become a
part of the Charter of this Village.
SECTION 4.  EFFECTIVE DATE OF CHARTER PROVISIONS.
   Schedule 1.   This Charter shall take effect and be in force upon approval
by the electors. Whenever, by virtue of the Constitution or laws of Ohio, the
Village of Evendale shall become a city, such city shall be deemed to be a
continuation of the Village of Evendale identical therewith, but by the name
"The City of Evendale," and this Charter, and all ordinances, resolutions,
contracts and other instruments whatsoever, shall continue with the same force
and effect in relation to the City of Evendale as to the Village of Evendale.
   Schedule 2.   Nothing in this Charter shall be construed in any way to
affect any contract entered into or any obligation incurred for the benefit of
the Village, before the taking effect of this Charter, or to repeal or impair
the force or effect of any ordinance or resolution  passed or adopted before
the taking effect of this Charter, except to the extent that such ordinance or
resolution may be inconsistent with any provision of this Charter, in which
event this Charter supersedes and replaces such ordinance or resolution.

Codified Ordinances

   CROSS REFERENCES
   See section histories for similar State law
   Codification in book form - see Ohio R.C. 731.23
   Imprisonment until fine paid - see Ohio R.C. 1905.30
   Ordinances and resolutions - see ADM. Ch.
222
   Statute of limitations on prosecutions - see GEN. OFF.
606.06
202.01  DESIGNATION; CITATION; HEADINGS.
   All ordinances and resolutions of a permanent and general nature of the
Municipality as revised and consolidated into component codes, titles, chapters
and sections shall be known and designated as the Codified Ordinances of
Evendale, Ohio, 1978, for which designation "Codified Ordinances" may be
substituted.  Code, title, chapter and section headings do not constitute any
part of the law as contained in the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.01)
202.02  GENERAL DEFINITIONS.
   As used in the Codified Ordinances, unless otherwise expressly provided or
the context otherwise requires:
   (a)   "And" may be read "or," and "or" may be read "and," if the sense
requires it.
   (b)   "Another," when used to designate the owner of property which is the
subject of an offense, includes not only natural persons but also every other
owner of property. 
   (c)   "Council" means the legislative authority of the Municipality.
   (d)   "County" means Hamilton County, Ohio.
   (e)   "Internet" means the international computer network of both federal
and non-federal interoperable packet switched data networks, including the
graphical subnetwork known as the world wide web.
   (f)   "Land" and "real estate" include rights and easements of an
incorporeal nature.
   (g)   "Municipality" or "Village" means the Village of Evendale, Ohio,
unless otherwise indicated.
   (h)   "OAC" refers to the Ohio Administrative Code.
   (i)   "Oath" includes affirmation and "swear" includes affirm.
   (j)   "Person" includes an individual, corporation, business trust, estate,
trust, partnership, and association.
   (k)   "Property" includes real, personal, and mixed estates and interests.
   (l)   "Registered mail" includes certified mail and "certified mail"
includes registered mail.
   (m)   "State" means the State of Ohio.
   (n)   "Week" means seven consecutive days. 
   (o)   "Whoever" includes all persons, natural and artificial; partners;
principals, agents, and employees; and all officials, public or private.
   (p)   "Written" or "in writing" includes any representation of words,
letters, symbols, or figures; this provision does not affect any law relating
to signatures.
   (q)   "Year" means twelve consecutive months.
(ORC 1.02, 1.05, 1.44, 1.59, 701.01)
202.03  RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)   Common and Technical Use.  Words and phrases shall be read in context
and construed according to the rules of grammar and common usage.  Words and
phrases that have acquired a technical or particular meaning, whether by
legislative definition or otherwise, shall be construed accordingly.
(ORC 1.42)
   (b)   Singular and Plural; Gender; Tense.
      (1)   The singular includes the plural, and the plural includes the
singular.
      (2)   Words of one gender include the other genders.
      (3)   Words in the present tense include the future.
(ORC 1.43)
   (c)   Computation of Time.
      (1)   The time within which an act is required by law to be done shall be
computed by excluding the first and including the last day; except that when
the last day falls on Sunday or a legal holiday, then the act may be done on
the next succeeding day which is not Sunday or a Legal holiday.
(ORC 1.14)
      (2)   When a public office, in which an act required by law is to be
performed, is closed to the public for the entire day that constitutes the last
day for doing the act or before its usual closing time on that day, the act may
be performed on the next succeeding day that is not a Sunday or a legal
holiday.
      (3)   "Legal holiday," as used in divisions (c)(1) and (c)(2) of this
section, means the following days:
         A.   The first day of January, known as New Year's day;
         B.   The third Monday in January, known as Martin Luther King day;
         C.   The third Monday in February, known as Washington-Lincoln day;
         D.   The day designated in the "Act of June 28, 1968," 82 Stat. 250, 5
U.S.C. 6103, as amended, for the commemoration of Memorial day;
         E.   The fourth day of July, known as Independence day;
         F.   The first Monday in September, known as Labor day;
         G.   The second Monday in October, known as Columbus day;
         H.   The eleventh day of November, known as Veteran's day;
         I.   The fourth Thursday in November, known as Thanksgiving day;
         J.   The twenty-fifth day of December, known as Christmas day;
         K.   Any day appointed and recommended by the Governor of this State
or the President of the United States as a holiday.
      (4)   If any day designated in this section as a legal holiday falls on a
Sunday, the next succeeding day is a legal holiday.
(ORC 1.14)
      (5)   If a number of months is to be computed by counting the months from
a particular day, the period ends on the same numerical day in the concluding
month as the day of the month from which the computation is begun, unless there
are not that many days in the concluding month, in which case the period ends
on the last day of that month.
(ORC 1.45)
      (6)   When an act is to take effect or become operative from and after a
day named, no part of that day shall be included.
(ORC 1.15)
202.04  REVIVOR; EFFECT OF REENACTMENT, AMENDMENT, OR REPEAL.
   (a)   The repeal of a repealing provision of the Codified Ordinances does
not revive the provision originally repealed nor impair the effect of any
saving clause therein.
(ORC 1.57)
   (b)   The reenactment, amendment, or repeal of a provision of the Codified
Ordinances does not, except as provided in subsection (c) hereof:
      (1)   Affect the prior operation of the provision or any prior action
taken thereunder;
      (2)   Affect any validation, cure, right, privilege, obligation, or
liability previously acquired, accrued, accorded, or incurred thereunder;
      (3)   Affect any violation thereof or penalty, forfeiture, or punishment
incurred in respect thereto, prior to the amendment or repeal;
      (4)   Affect any investigation, proceeding, or remedy in respect of any
such privilege, obligation, liability, penalty, forfeiture or punishment; and
the investigation, proceeding, or remedy may be instituted, continued, or
enforced, and the penalty, forfeiture, or punishment imposed, as if the
provision had not been repealed or amended.
   (c)   If the penalty, forfeiture, or punishment for any offense is reduced
by a reenactment or amendment of a provision of the Codified Ordinances, the
penalty, forfeiture, or punishment, if not already imposed, shall be imposed
according to the provision as amended.
(ORC 1.58)
202.05  CONSTRUCTION OF SECTION REFERENCES.
   (a)   A reference to any portion of a provision of the Codified Ordinances
applies to all reenactments or amendments thereof.
(ORC 1.55)
   (b)   Wherever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a
series of sections, or of subsections or other subdivisions of a section, such
reference shall be construed to mean a violation of any section, subsection or
other such subdivision included in such reference.
   (c)   References in the Codified Ordinances to action taken or authorized
under designated sections of the Codified Ordinances include, in every case,
action taken or authorized under the applicable legislative provision which is
superseded by the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.23)
202.06  SEPARABILITY.
   If any provisions of a section of the Codified Ordinances or the application
thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not
affect other provisions or applications of the section or related sections
which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to
this end the provisions are severable.
(ORC 1.50)
202.99  GENERAL PENALTY.
   Whenever, in the Codified Ordinances or in any ordinance of the
Municipality, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an
offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the
failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is
otherwise provided, whoever violates or fails to comply with any such provision
is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00).  A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day
during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.

   EDITOR'S NOTE: There are no sections in Chapter 204. This chapter has been
established to provide a place for cross references and any future legislation.
   CROSS REFERENCES

CHAPTER 206
Public Meetings
206.01   Purposes; application.
206.02   Definitions.
206.03   Notice of regular and organizational meetings.
206.04   Notice of special meetings.
206.05   Notice to news media of special meetings.
206.06   Notification of discussion of specific types of public businesses.
206.07   General regulations.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Annual Town Meeting - see CHTR.
Art. I, § 7
   Council meetings - see CHTR.,
Art. II, § 1; ADM.
220.01
   Public meetings - see Ohio R.C. 121.22
206.01  PURPOSES; APPLICATION.
   The provisions of this chapter constitute the Rules for Notification of
Meetings to the Public and News Media and are adopted, pursuant to Ohio R.C.
121.22(F) for the purposes of:
   (a)   Establishing a reasonable method for any person to determine the time
and place of all regularly scheduled meetings and the time, place and purpose
of all special meetings;
   (b)   Making provisions for giving advance notice of special meetings to the
news media that have requested notification; and
   (c)   Making provisions for persons to request and obtain reasonable advance
notification of all meetings at which any specific type of public business is
to be discussed.
   These Rules apply to each Municipal body, as defined in Section
206.02, of this Village and are in addition to any applicable legal
requirements as to notices to members of a Municipal body or to others in
connection with specific meetings or specific subject matters.
(Ord. 34-75. Passed 12-4-75.)
206.02  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Clerk" means the Village Clerk.
   (b)   "Day" means a calendar day.
   (c)   "Meeting" means any prearranged discussion of the public business of a
Municipal body by a majority of the members of the Municipal body.
   (d)   "Municipal body" means any of the following: Council, the Village
Planning Commission, the Zoning Board of Appeals, the Architectural Review
Board and the Public Recreation Commission, and committees of these Municipal
bodies comprised of members of such bodies if such committees are:
      (1)   Comprised of a majority of the members of the main Municipal body;
or
      (2)   Decision-making committees.
   (e)   "Oral notification" means notification given orally, either in person
or by telephone, directly to the person for whom such notification is intended,
or by leaving an oral message for such person at the address, or if by
telephone at the telephone number, of such person as shown on the records kept
by the Clerk under this chapter.
   (f)   "Post" means to post in an area accessible to the public during the
usual business hours at the office of the Clerk and outside the Council
Chambers Lobby of the Recreation Building.  A notice identifying the location
at which notifications will be posted pursuant to this chapter shall be
published by the Clerk within ten calendar days after the adoption of this
chapter.
   (g)   "Published" means published once in a newspaper having a general
circulation in the Municipality, as defined in Ohio R.C. 7.12, except that no
portion of such newspaper need be printed in the Municipality.
   (h)   "Special meeting" means a meeting which is neither a regular meeting
nor an adjournment of a regular or special meeting to another time or day to
consider items specifically stated on the original agenda of such regular or
special meeting.
   (i)   "Written notification" means notification in writing mailed,
telegraphed or delivered to the address of the person for whom such
notification is intended as shown on the records kept by the Clerk under this
chapter, or in any way delivered to such person. If mailed, such notification
shall be mailed by first-class mail, deposited in a U.S. Postal Service mailbox
not later than the second day preceding the day of the meeting to which such
notification refers, provided that at least one regular mail delivery day falls
between the day of mailing and the day of such meeting.
(Ord. 34-75. Passed 12-4-75.)
206.03  NOTICE OF REGULAR AND ORGANIZATIONAL MEETINGS.
   (a)   The Clerk shall post a statement of the time(s) and place(s) of
regular meetings of each Municipal body for each calendar year not later than
the second day preceding the day of the first regular meeting (other than the
organizational meeting) of the calendar year of that Municipal body. The Clerk
shall check at reasonable intervals to ensure that such statement remains so
posted during such calendar year. If at any time during the calendar year the
time or place of regular meetings, or of any regular meeting, is changed on a
permanent or temporary basis, a statement of the time and place of such changed
regular meetings shall be so posted by the Clerk at least twenty-four hours
before the time of the first changed regular meeting.
   (b)   The Clerk shall post a statement of the time and place of any
organizational meeting of a Municipal body at least twenty-four hours before
the time of such organizational meeting.
   (c)   Upon the adjournment of any regular or special meeting to another day,
the Clerk shall promptly post notice of the time and place of such adjourned
meeting.
(Ord. 34-75. Passed 12-4-75.)
206.04  NOTICE OF SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (a)   Except in the case of a special meeting referred to in Section
206.05(d), the Clerk shall, not later than twelve hours before the time of a
special meeting of a Municipal body, post a statement of the time, place and
purposes of such special meeting.
   (b)   The statement under this section and the notifications under Section
206.05 shall state such specific or general purpose or purposes then known to
the Clerk to be intended to be considered at such special meeting and may
state, as an additional general purpose, that any other business as may
properly come before such Municipal body at such meeting may be considered and
acted upon.
(Ord. 34-75. Passed 12-4-75.)
206.05  NOTICE TO NEWS MEDIA OF SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (a)   Any news medium organization that desires to be given advance
notification of special meetings of a Municipal body shall file with the Clerk
a written request therefor.
   Except in the event of an emergency requiring immediate official action, as
referred to in subsection (d) hereof, a special meeting shall not be held
unless at least twenty-four hours advance notice of the time, place and
purposes of such special meeting is given to the news media that have requested
such advance notification in accordance with subsection (b) hereof.
   (b)   News media requests for such advance notification of special meetings
shall specify: the Municipal body that is the subject of such request; the name
of the medium; the name and address of the person to whom written notification
to the medium may be mailed, telegraphed or delivered; and the names, addresses
and telephone numbers (including addresses and telephone numbers at which
notifications may be given either during or outside of business hours) of at
least two persons to either one of whom oral notification to the medium may be
given.
   Any such request shall be effective for one year from the date of filing
with the Clerk or until the Clerk receives written notice from such medium
canceling or modifying such request, whichever is earlier. Each requesting news
medium shall be informed of such period of effectiveness at the time it files
its request. Such requests may be modified or extended only by filing a
complete new request with the Clerk. A request shall not be deemed to be made
unless it is complete in all respects, and such request may be conclusively
relied on by the Village, the Municipal body that is the subject of such
request and the Clerk.
   (c)   The Clerk shall give such oral notification or written notification,
or both, as the Clerk determines, to the news media that have requested such
advance notification in accordance with subsection (b) hereof, of the time,
place and purposes of each special meeting, at least twenty-four hours prior to
the time of such special meeting.
   (d)   In the event of an emergency requiring immediate official action, a
special meeting may be held without giving twenty-four hours advance
notification thereof to the requesting news media. The persons calling such
meeting, or any one or more of such persons or the Clerk on their behalf, shall
immediately give oral notification or written notification, or both, as the
person or persons giving such notification determine, of the time, place and
purposes of such special meeting to such news media that have requested such
advance notification in accordance with subsection (b) hereof. The minutes or
the call, or both, of any such special meeting shall state the general nature
of the emergency requiring immediate official action.
(Ord. 34-75. Passed 12-4-75.)
206.06  NOTIFICATION OF DISCUSSION OF SPECIFIC TYPES OF PUBLIC BUSINESS.
   Any person, upon written request and as provided herein, may obtain
reasonable advance notification of all meetings at which any specific type of
public business is scheduled to be discussed.
   Such person may file a written request with the Clerk specifying the
person's name and the address(es) and telephone number(s) at or through which
the person can be reached during and outside of business hours; the specific
type of public business the discussion of which the person is requesting
advance notification of; the Municipal body that is the subject of such
request; and the number of calendar months (not to exceed twelve) which the
request covers. Such request may be canceled by request from such person to the
Clerk.
   Such requests may be modified or extended only by filing a complete new
request with the Clerk. A request shall not be deemed to be made unless it is
complete in all respects, and such request may be conclusively relied on by the
Village, the Municipal body that is the subject of such request, and the Clerk.
   The contents of written notification under this section may be a copy of the
agenda of the meeting. Written notification under this section may be
accomplished by giving advance written notification, by copies of the agendas,
of all meetings of the Municipal body that is the subject of such request.
(Ord. 34-75. Passed 12-4-75.)
206.07  GENERAL REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Any person may visit or telephone the office of the Clerk during that
office's regular hours to determine, based on information available at that
office: the time and place of regular meetings; the time, place and purposes of
any then known special meetings; and whether or not the available agenda of any
such future meeting states that any specific type of public business,
identified by such person, is to be discussed at such meeting.
   (b)   Any notification provided herein to be given by the Clerk may be given
by any person acting on behalf of or under the authority of the Clerk.
   (c)   A reasonable attempt at notification shall constitute notification in
compliance with this chapter.
(Ord. 34-75. Passed 12-4-75.)
