220.01  MEETINGS.
   Council shall hold its regular meetings at 7:00 p.m. on the second Tuesday
of each month at the Municipal Building unless the majority of Council shall
determine that a different date is necessary in any particular month, in which
case said change of date shall be publicly announced and posted on the
Village’s web site.
(Ord. 5-58.  Passed 2-6-58; Ord. 04-01. Passed 1-8-04; Ord. 11-04.  Passed 1-
13-11.)
220.02  EXPENSES.
   Members of Council shall be paid the expenses incurred in performing their
duties and conducting the affairs of the Village. 
(Ord. 2-51.  Passed 6-12-51.)
220.03  VOTING PROCEDURES.
   (a)   The rules of procedure relative to voting and tabulation of votes as
set forth in the Robert's Rules of Order are modified as hereinafter set forth
and shall supersede Robert's Rules of Order where there is a conflict relative
to procedures governing Council voting and tabulation of votes.
   (b)   All members in attendance of any Council meeting shall respond with a
yes or no vote or an abstention.
   (c)   All responses by members of Council reflecting an abstention for any
reason, or any response other than "yes" shall be counted as a negative vote.
(Res. 2-86. Passed 2-6-86)
CHAPTER 222
Ordinances and Resolutions
222.01   Publication; posting.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Initiative and referendum - see CHTR.
Art. I, Sec. 5
   Time of taking effect - see CHTR.
Art. II, Sec. 4
   Emergency measures - see CHTR.

Art. II, Sec. 6
222.01  PUBLICATION; POSTING.
   (a)   Publication.
      (1)   Publication of ordinances, resolutions and statements, orders,
proclamations, notices, and reports required by law or ordinance to be
published shall be published by publication thereof in any newspaper printed in
Hamilton County and of general circulation in the Village.  Ordinances and
resolutions may be published by title only.  An affidavit of the proprietor of
such newspaper shall be sufficient proof of publication.
      (2)   All matters provided in subsection (a)(1) hereof shall be published
once except notice to bidders for construction of public improvements and
notices of the sale of bonds, which shall be published twice on two consecutive
weeks.
      (3)   If revision and codification of ordinances and resolutions is made,
and such revision and codification contains new matter, it shall be sufficient
publication to publish a notice of the enactment of such codifying ordinance,
containing the title of the ordinance and a summary of the new matters covered
by it.  Such revision and codification may be made under appropriate titles,
chapter, sections and in one ordinance containing one or more subjects.
   (b)   Posting.
      (1)   All ordinances, resolutions and statements, orders, proclamations,
notices, and reports required by law or ordinance to be published, shall, in
addition to publication as hereinabove set forth in subsection (a), be posted
within seven days of enactment by the Clerk of Evendale Municipal Building.
      (2)   The purpose of the posting of the above ordinances, resolutions,
statements, orders, proclamations, notices, and reports as hereinabove set
forth is for the purpose of allowing residents of the community further
notification of the actions of Council, but any failure of said posting
requirements shall not in any way affect the proclamation, notice, and report.
(Ord. 44-84. Passed 8-2-84.)

230.01  CONTRACTS FOR SUPPLEMENTARY PERSONNEL.
   (a)   The Mayor is authorized and directed to employ, by contract, a person
or persons for the purpose of supplementing the service crew and maintenance
personnel for miscellaneous jobs and general handyman activity.  No such
contract shall exceed one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500) and the
contract for each job shall be in writing on a form satisfactory to the Village
Solicitor and filed with the Chief Fiscal and Accounting Officer before
commencement of any work.
   (b)   The cost of such work and payment of such contracts shall be from the
General Fund, Code 4-235-71.3. 
(Ord. 48-70.  Passed 7-2-70; Ord. 05-34.  Passed 8-11-05.)
230.02  EXPENSES.
   The Mayor shall be paid the expenses incurred in performing his duties and
conducting the affairs of the Village. 
(Ord. 2-51.  Passed 6-12-51.)
230.03  COOPERATIVE PURCHASING.
   (a)   The Mayor requests authority in the name of the Village to participate
in state contracts which the Department of Administrative Services, Office of
State Purchasing has entered into for the purchase of supplies, services,
equipment, and certain materials pursuant to Ohio R.C. 125.04.
   (b)   The Mayor is authorized to agree in the name of the Village to be
bound by all contract terms and conditions as the Department of Administrative
Service, Office of State Purchasing prescribes.  Such terms and conditions may
include a reasonable fee to cover the administrative costs which the Department
of Administrative Services incurs as a result of Village participation in a
contract.  The Mayor agrees to be bound by all such terms and conditions.
   (c)   The Mayor is authorized to agree in the name of the Village to
directly pay the vendor, under each such state contract in which it
participates, for items it receives pursuant to the contract.  The Mayor agrees
to directly pay the vendor.
(Res. 5-88.  Passed 3-3-88.)
230.04  PROCEDURES FOR SUCCESSION OF VILLAGE OFFICIALS.
   (a)   As used in this section the term "temporary absence" means either
being continuously outside of the corporate limits of the Village of Evendale
for a period of seven consecutive days or being outside the corporate limits of
the Village of Evendale for a shorter period of time which prevents the
execution of the duty to preside over a council meeting, Mayor's Court or the
execution of documents required for the proper functioning of the Village of
Evendale.
   (b)   As used in this section "disability" means a physical or mental
condition which substantially impairs or prevents the exercise of the powers
and duties of Mayor as described in the Charter of the Village of Evendale.
   (c)   (1)   Whenever the Mayor intends to be on a "temporary absence" from
the Village of Evendale, the Mayor shall, prior to the absence, deliver a
written notice to the Clerk stating the time at which the absence will begin
and the time it will end.
      (2)   The Clerk shall keep the notice in the records of the Village of
Evendale and immediately deliver copies of the notice to the Vice Mayor and
President of Pro Tempore of Council and all Council members.
      (3)   Upon receipt of the Notice, the Vice-Mayor shall execute an
acknowledgment that he has been notified of the absence of the Mayor and
indicate either that he will or will not be on a "temporary absence" from the
Village of Evendale during all or part of the "temporary absence" of the
Mayor.  Upon execution of the acknowledgment stating that he will not be on
temporary absence at the same time as the Mayor, the Vice Mayor shall exercise
the powers and perform the duties of the Mayor during the "temporary absence".
      (4)   Should the Vice Mayor, in executing the acknowledgment described in
subdivision (c)(3) of this section, indicate that he will be on "temporary
absence" during all or part of the "temporary absence" of the Mayor, the
President Pro Tempore of Council shall execute an acknowledgment that he will
exercise the powers and perform the duties of the Mayor during the "temporary
absence" of the Mayor.
      (5)   Should the Clerk be unable to locate the Vice Mayor to serve him
with notice of the "temporary absence" of the Mayor, the Clerk shall execute an
affidavit stating the steps taken to locate the Vice Mayor and the President
Pro Tempore shall execute the acknowledgment that the Mayor and Vice-Mayor are
temporarily absent from the Village of Evendale.  The President Pro Tempore
shall, during the "temporary absence" of the Mayor, exercise the powers and
duties of the Mayor until the Vice Mayor is located and executes the
acknowledgment described in subdivision (c)(3) of this section.
   (d)   (1)   Should any councilmember or officer of the Village of Evendale
learn of the incapacity of the Mayor (or the Vice Mayor when exercising the
powers and duties of the Mayor) the councilmember or officer shall describe the
condition in an affidavit and serve it upon the Clerk.  The Clerk shall retain
a copy of the affidavit in her records and cause copies of it to be served upon
the Council. Should three or more members of Council reasonably believe the
disability of the Mayor, (or Vice Mayor when exercising the powers and duties
of the Mayor) exists they shall cause a special meeting of Council to occur as
provided by Article II, Section 1 of the charter of the Village of Evendale.
      (2)   At the special meeting the Council shall determine whether the
disability of the Mayor (or Vice Mayor exercising the powers and duties of the
Mayor) exists.  If the Mayor (or Vice Mayor exercising the powers and duties of
Mayor) appears at the special meeting or at the request of any councilmember,
action shall be tabled for a period not to exceed two weeks for an independent
medical examination to be secured. At the special meeting, or the meeting to
which the matter of the disability of the Mayor (or the Vice Mayor when
exercising the powers and duties of the Mayor) is tabled, the council may
consider the independent medical examiners report, the cooperation of the Mayor
(or Vice Mayor exercising the powers and duties of the Mayor) with the
independent medical examination, affidavits or evidence demonstrating whether
the disability exists. Should the council find the disability exists the
Council shall determine the existence of the disability by resolution. The
resolution shall be approved by no less than five (5) members of Council. The
resolution shall state the expected duration of the disability and that the
Mayor (or Vice Mayor exercising the powers and duties of Mayor) may at any time
present new evidence to the Council that the disability no longer exists.
   (e)   Whenever the Vice Mayor exercising the powers and duties of the Mayor
intends to take a temporary absence from the Village of Evendale, he shall
execute the notice described in subdivision (c)(3) as if he were the Mayor. The
acknowledgment of the notice shall be executed by the President Pro Tempore of
the Council.
(Ord. 97-87. Passed 2-5-98.)

   CROSS REFERENCES

Art. IV, Sec. 4
238.01  DUTIES OF ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT.
   The administrative Assistant shall:
   (a)   Maintain and develop economic development projects.
   (b)   Act as secretary to Council committees or as designated by Mayor.
   (c)   Review and evaluate all contract employees and contract services.
   (d)   Coordinate maintenance of the Village grounds, buildings, and
facilities.
   (e)   Assist the Mayor in resolving departmental jurisdictional disputes.
   (f)   Represent the Mayor at administrative functions and/or Village
programs relating to all departments at the Mayor's request.
   (g)   Keep informed of developments in county, state, and federal funding
programs, reporting to the Mayor and Council periodically, and initiating
appropriate action to participate in selected programs at the discretion of
Council.
   (h)   Prepare reports as instructed by the Mayor.
   (i)   Provide the Mayor and Council with progress reports relative to
capital expenditures.
   (j)   Assist the Mayor in maintaining personnel records and administering
the personnel code.
   (k)   Assist the Mayor and Council in resolving questions or complaints from
the residential and business communities for the Village. This duty includes,
but is not limited to:
      (1)   The responsibility to act as a liaison between municipal operations
and businesses and residents;
      (2)   The establishment of effective two way communications until
problems or questions are resolved.
   (l)   Assist the Mayor in evaluating Village services and make
recommendations.
   (m)   Aid and advise Village officials on record retention programs,
consistent with legal requirements.
   (n)   Perform other duties assigned by the Mayor.
(Ord. 65-88.  Passed 10-6-88)
238.02  POLITICAL SIGNS ON THE VILLAGE CAMPUS ON ELECTION DAY.
   The Director of Administrative Services of the Village is hereby authorized
and directed to designate an area or areas on the Village of Evendale campus
where political signs of candidates or ballot issue proponents or opponents may
post political signs on any election day. Such signs may be no larger than a
total of eight square feet in size including both sides of a two sided sign,
and be installed no earlier than 10:00 p.m. on the day before the election and
must be removed by 10:00 p.m.  Signs installed on Village property prior to
such time or remaining after such time or posted in undesignated areas may be
confiscated and disposed of by the Village.  Signs may only be installed in a
manner that does not damage Village property. The cost of repairing any damage
to Village property caused by such signs shall be assessed against the campaign
or campaigns of the candidate or candidates or issue supporters or opponents on
whose behalf such signs were installed. The location where signs may be
installed must be no closer than 100 feet from the door of the building or
buildings in which voting is taking place. All candidates and ballot issue
proponents and opponents shall have an equal right to post said signs.
(Ord. 17-03.  Passed 2-14-17.)

240.01  PERSONNEL.
   The Police Department shall be composed of a Chief of Police and such other
officers and personnel as Council shall from time to time determine.
240.02  SCOPE OF EMPLOYMENT.
   Any action taken by any member of the Police Department outside the
territorial limits of the Village, or if taken in the line of cooperation upon
official police business with any of the other governmental units of Hamilton
County, which action is ordered or approved by the Chief of Police of the
Village of Evendale, or if done on an emergency basis, is subsequently ratified
by such Chief of Police, shall be considered to be an action performed in the
course of his employment by such member of the Police Department.
(Res. 2-58.  Passed 10-2-58.)
240.03  ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION FOR OFF-DUTY WORK.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized to approve additional payments to members of
the Police Department for additional duty they perform from time to time in
their off hours at the request of business houses, industrial plants and the
like, on special occasions.  Such additional payments shall be reasonable and
not exceed the amount the Village receives for providing such special service
by off-duty Police Department members.
(Ord. 20-61.  Passed 5-4-61.)
240.04  DOG WARDEN.
   (a)   The Mayor may from time to time appoint a Dog Warden from the
membership of the Police Department, when he or she is satisfied that the
appointee has completed a suitable course of study and has the necessary
qualifications.  Any such appointment may be terminated by the Mayor when the
public convenience requires the same or when the Dog Warden is no longer a
Village police officer.
   (b)   The police officer so appointed shall act as Dog Warden during his or
her off-duty hours under the supervision of the Chief of Police, and shall wear
suitable attire for the added enforcement of
Chapter 618, as designated by the Chief.  The officer appointed as Dog Warden
shall be compensated at regular hourly rates of pay for such work.  Appropriate
equipment and transportation for the work shall be furnished by the Village, as
well as legal identification of the officer's status as Dog Warden.
(Ord. 32-78.  Passed 8-3-78.)
240.05  SUPPLEMENTAL PERSONNEL RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The "Rules and Regulations of the Evendale Police Department," attached as
Appendix A to and made a part of Ord. 22-87, are adopted in accordance with the
Personnel Code of the Village and Section
258.36, and shall be applicable and have full force and effect relative to the
operation of the Village Police Department and the personnel of that
department.
(Ord. 22-87.  Passed 2-19-87; Ord. 32-88. Passed 6-2-88)
240.06  LAW ENFORCEMENT FUND.
   There is hereby established a special revenue fund to be known as the "Law
Enforcement Fund" under the provisions of Ohio R.C. 2933.43.  The necessity for
establishing a Law Enforcement Fund is to provide for the recording of the
proceeds from the public auctions of contraband seized by public safety forces
within the Village.  Initial funding for this special revenue fund will be
received from the public auction of such contraband.
(Res. 30-87.  Passed 12-3-87.)
240.07  DRUG LAW ENFORCEMENT FUND.
   There is hereby established a special revenue fund to be known as the "Drug
Law Enforcement Fund" under the provisions of Ohio R.C. 2933.43.  The necessity
for establishing a Drug Law Enforcement Fund is to provide for separate
accounting records for fines, or portions thereof, collected under that section
of the Ohio Revised Code.  Initial funding for this special revenue fund will
be received from the presiding court from which the fines would be levied.
(Res. 30-87.  Passed 12-3-87.)
240.08  RESPONSIBILITIES OF CHIEF.
   (a)   Chief executive officer. The Chief of Police is chief executive
officer of the Police Department and is responsible for the protection of the
lives and property in the Village of Evendale through the supervision of all
police functions.
      (1)   The Chief of Police is responsible for organizing, controlling and
directing the personnel and resources of the Department.
      (2)   The Chief of Police is in the unclassified service and serves in
accordance with the provisions of the Charter and ordinances of the Village of
Evendale; functioning in accordance with the general policy established by the
Mayor and the Village Council, with considerable latitude in the exercise of
independent judgment and discretion in the management of and operation of the
Police Department.
(Ord. 51-88. Passed 8-4-88.)
   (b)   Fiscal management.
      (1)   The Chief of Police is responsible for the overall fiscal
management of the Police Department. He shall work closely with the Mayor and
the Chief Fiscal and Accounting Officer or, if there is none, the Clerk of the
Village in fiscal matters. The Chief of Police is responsible to supervise and
approve the budget recommendations and purchase requests subject to the Charter
and ordinances of the Village of Evendale.
      (2)   The Chief Fiscal and Accounting Officer of the Village of Evendale
is responsible to maintain accurate accounting of all funds allocated to the
Police Department, conduct purchasing as provided by the Charter and ordinances
of the Village of Evendale and keep the Chief of Police apprised on the status
of the various accounts.
(Ord. 50-88. Passed 8-4-88; Ord. 05-34.  Passed 8-11-05.)
240.09  POLICE SPECIALIST.
   (a)   The positions of "specialist" is established within the rank
classification of police officer in the Police Department. The "Specialist"
designation is to recognize and compensate patrol officers who assume and
maintain certain skills, knowledge and abilities to perform additional duties
crucial to the agency, but which are not necessarily supervisory in nature.
   (b)   Each year the Police Chief when appropriate shall recommend to the
Mayor and Village Council those positions which have been identified though a
job task analysis and evaluation of the current and anticipated future needs of
the Department, as being crucial to the efficient operation of the Police
Department by way of having a "specialist" appointed for that need and job.
   (c)   The Mayor and Village Council shall determine the numbers of
Specialists and the amount, if any, of additional compensation which may be
paid to officers in these specialist positions.
   (d)   Each year, where appropriate, the Mayor with the approval of the
Council of the Village shall make the appointment of said temporary specialists
to the specific "specialist" job for a period not to exceed one year.
   (e)   Appointment to the Specialist position shall be temporary in nature,
with each appointment for a period of one year (January 1 through December 31).
All appointments as specialists shall be subject to termination in the event of
disciplinary procedures as provided in the Evendale Personnel Code Rules and
Regulations. Police Officers who have been previously appointed as Specialists
shall maintain the same seniority, pay grade, and all other benefits pertinent
to the position of Patrol Officer but shall not receive the extra compensation
received when said officer was appointed and acting in the capacity of a
specialist and whose "Specialist" appointment has expired at the end of the
calendar year of their appointment.
   (f)   The Mayor shall maintain on file position descriptions for all current
Specialist positions listing the duties, responsibilities, and minimum
qualifications for appointment to the position.
(Ord. 47-89. Passed 8-3-89.)
240.10  APPROPRIATE USE OF LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND.
   (a)   The Council of the Village of Evendale, the legislative authority for
the Evendale Police Department does hereby determine that the appropriate use
of the law enforcement trust fund in addition to those uses specified in Ohio
R.C. 2943.44 shall be payment of overtime to police officers on Fridays,
Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays for increased patrol activity to discourage
drug trafficking and usage.  The activities shall include:
      (1)   Enforcement of driving under the influence of drugs and/or alcohol
offenses by an enhanced traffic law enforcement program.
      (2)   Drug interdiction/enforcement program whereby an officer will
increase patrols at motels and restaurant areas to discourage drug activity.
      (3)   Warrant service enforcement which has a priority of locating person
for whom arrest warrants have been issued.
   (b)   The Chief of Police shall establish a policy detailing the activities
of each officer participating in an overtime shift under division (a) of this
section.  The policy shall require the signature of a supervisor verifying that
the duties of the police officer under this program were limited to those set
out in division (a) of this section and the policy established by the Chief of
Police.
   (c)   The Chief Fiscal and Accounting Officer shall deposit all such monies
into the Law Enforcement Trust Fund (line item 208-101.000-151.006, "Forfeited/
seized monies/property"), ten percent of which shall be transferred to the Drug
Law Enforcement Fund (line item 209-101.000-151.006 "Forfeited/seized monies/
property"), and it shall be used exclusively for DARE Programs and other
programs designed to educate adults or children with respect to the dangers
associated with the use of drugs or abuse.
   (d)   The remaining 90% of the funds (remaining in the Law Enforcement Trust
Fund) shall be used exclusively for purposes set out in division (a) of this
section.
(Ord. 96-29. Passed 4-4-96; Ord. 05-34.  Passed 8-11-05.)
240.11   OFFICER IN CHARGE.
   When neither the Police Chief nor any lieutenants or sergeants are on duty,
the most senior patrol officer then on duty shall constitute the Officer in
Charge. While serving as the Officer in Charge, his or her rate of pay shall be
increased by one dollar ($1.00) per hour from what it is otherwise.
(Ord. 04-70.  Passed 12-9-04.)

officers and personnel as Council shall from time to time determine.

November 11, 2014.)
242.03  BACKGROUND INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANTS.
   (a)   Each applicant for membership in the Fire Department shall furnish a
classifiable set of fingerprints to the Police Department.
   (b)   The Chief of Police, and members of the Police Department acting in
his name, are hereby authorized to conduct a field investigation and are hereby
directed to conduct criminal records checks of each applicant for employment by
the Fire Department.
   (c)   The Chief of Police or a member of the Police Department acting on his
behalf shall prepare a factual summary of the background investigation and
criminal records check of each firefighter applicant and transmit such summary
to the Fire Chief for the purpose of determining the fitness of an applicant.
The summary may contain recom mendations to the Fire Chief concerning the
suitability for employment of a firefighter applicant.
   (d)   Background investigations and records checks include records of all
arrests and dispositions as an adult. Records of arrests and dispositions while
an applicant was considered a juvenile shall be transmitted only when
authorized by court order, court rule, court decision, Federal regulation or
State statute.
   (e)   Criminal history records and information shall include arrest and
disposition data on file in the National Crime Information Center, the Federal
Bureau of Investigation, the Department of Defense and all other Federal, State
and local law enforcement agencies.
   (f)   Any applicant for membership in the Fire Department who is denied
employment on the basis of the investigation summary referred to in this
section may inspect that summary for the purpose of clarifying, explaining or
denying the accuracy of its contents.
   (g)   The Chief of Police and members of the Police Department shall make no
dissemination to the Fire Chief regarding the fitness of firefighter applicants
other than that contained in the official summary report referred to in this
section.
(Ord. 45-76. Passed 10-7-76.)
242.04  COOPERATIVE PURCHASING OF EQUIPMENT AND SUPPLIES.
   (a)   The Mayor is authorized in the name of the Village of Evendale to
cooperate in contracts for the purchase of equipment in which the Chiefs or
Fire Chiefs of Southwestern Ohio have entered into for the purchase of
supplies, service, equipment, and materials for the Evendale Fire Department,
which participation in said contract shall not exceed $3,500.
   (b)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to agree in the name of the Village of
Evendale to be bound by all contract terms and conditions of the purchasing
organization subject to being responsible for the payment for only those pieces
of equipment, supplies, services and materials furnished to the Village of
Evendale Fire Department and subject to the Charter limitation that any
obligation shall not exceed $10,000.
   (c)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to agree in the name of the Village of
Evendale to directly pay the vendor under each such contract in which the
Village of Evendale participates, for items it has received pursuant to such
contract, and the Mayor shall pay for those items and services under said
contract rendered to the Village of Evendale Fire Department directly to the
vendor.
(Ord. 64-88. Passed 10-6-88)

248.01  ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby created a Tax Department for the Village to be staffed with
such personnel having such duties as Council shall from time to time determine.
248.02  CHIEF FISCAL AND ACCOUNTING OFFICER OR, IF THERE IS NONE, VILLAGE CLERK
AS TAX ADMINISTRATOR.
   The functions and duties of the Tax Administrator as provided in
Chapter 890 of the Business Regulation and Taxation Code shall be overseen by
the Chief Fiscal and Accounting Officer or, if there is none, by the Village
Clerk. The Village, by action of Council and the Mayor, may establish the
separate position of Tax Administrator. However, if there is no separate
position of Tax Administrator, the Chief Fiscal or Accounting Officer or, if
there is none, the Village Clerk, shall be the Tax Administrator and shall use
the title Tax Administrator for all actions as Tax Administrator. Where the
Chief Fiscal and Accounting Officer or the Village Clerk is also the Tax
Administrator, Council may establish an additional amount of compensation for
carrying out the duties of Tax Administrator.
(Ord. 12-77.  Passed 4-7-77; Ord. 05-34.  Passed 8-11-05.)

Civil Defense
   EDITOR'S NOTE: Resolution 17-51, passed August 7, 1951, authorized the
Village to Affiliate with the Hamilton County Civil Defense organization, and
the Mayor to appoint a Village Director of Civil Defense. Resolution 8-57,
passed June 11, 1957, authorized execution of a revised civil defense
organization agreement as set forth in the letter of the Board Chairman of the
Ohio Valley Civil Defense Authority. Previously, Ordinance 1-53, passed January
6, 1953 (as amended by Ordinances 11-1954, passed August 3, 1954, and 21-55,
passed December 20, 1955), authorized the Mayor to contract with the Hamilton
County Commissioners in the formation of the Cincinnati-Hamilton County Civil
Defense Organization pursuant to Ohio R.C. 5915.06. The state legislature in
1988 amended Chapter 5915 to change the name of the civil defense agency to
emergency management agency and make other changes in the civil defense law. 
   Ordinance 45-81, passed August 6, 1981, adopted a Crisis Relocation Plan for
the public safety in the event of a threatened nuclear attack.

provide a place for cross references and any future legislation.

230.01
PURPOSE AND POLICIES
258.001  POLICIES.
   (a)   Policies, including internal department policies/procedures, are
defined as the basic rules which guide administrative action for accomplishing
an organization's objectives. Comprehensive and clearly defined policies,
consistently and fairly administered, are essential to the success of any
organization.
   (b)   The policies as set forth by the Village of Evendale are contained
herein. All personnel charged with the responsibility of administering policy
must be thoroughly knowledgeable of the contents. Furthermore, it is essential
that these policies be administered in a systematic, fair, and impartial
manner.
   (c)   Undoubtedly, there will be situations that require administrative
interpretations of the policies set forth herein. Every effort must be made to
insure that such decisions are made objectively, with the general intent of
this policy in mind.
   (d)   As conditions change within the Village's organization, it may be
necessary to add, delete, or revise specific policies affected by such change.
The content of all such policy changes will be made known to all affected
employees.
   (e)   These policies are to be utilized by administrative and supervisory
employees to ensure uniformity and nondiscriminatory application of the
conditions of employment.
(Ord. 97-40.  Passed 4-2-98; Ord. 18-15.  Passed 2-13-18.)
258.002  OBJECTIVES.
   The Village of Evendale recognizes that a personnel system which recruits
and retains competent, dependable personnel is indispensable to effective
Village government. The policies set forth herein are designed to:
   (a)   Promote high morale and foster good working relationships among
Village employees by providing uniform personnel policies, equal opportunities
for advancement, and consideration for employee needs;
   (b)   Encourage internal promotional practices which enhance the
attractiveness of a career with the Village, and enables employees to give
their best efforts to the Village and the public;
   (c)   Inspire courteous and dependable service to the public;
   (d)   Provide fair and equal opportunity for qualified persons to enter and
progress in Village service based on merit and fitness as determined through
objective and practical personnel management methods; and
   (e)   Ensure that all operations are conducted in an ethical and legal
manner so as to promote the
Village's reputation as an efficient, progressive body in the community and the
state.
(Ord. 97-40.  Passed 4-2-98; Ord. 18-15.  Passed 2-13-19.)
258.003  NONDISCRIMINATION.
   (a)   The Village shall not discriminate against any employee on the basis
of age, race, color, sex, sexual orientation, gender expression, marital
status, military status, creed, religion, national origin (ancestry), handicap,
or disability (Appendix A). The Village, however, reserves the right to
establish bona fide occupational qualifications, which all employees and
prospective employees must satisfy as a term or condition of employment.
   (b)   The Village of Evendale is an equal opportunity employer (Appendix B).
It is the desire of the Village to maintain an affirmative action plan which
assures equal employment opportunity. Violations of the plan by any employee of
the Village are considered failure of good behavior and are subject to
disciplinary action.
(Ord. 97-40.  Passed 4-2-98; Ord. 18-15.  Passed 2-13-18.)
APPLICABILITY
258.010  SCOPE OF COVERAGE.
   These policies apply to all employees.
(Ord. 97-40.  Passed 4-2-98; Ord. 18-15.  Passed 2-13-18.)
258.011  DISCLAIMER.
   (a)   The policies set forth and adopted herein supersede all previous
written and unwritten personnel policies of the Village of Evendale. These
policies have been structured so as to comply with any and all applicable
Federal and State laws and agreements. In the event there is a conflict between
the matters expressed in these policies and any applicable laws or agreements,
the applicable law or full text of the written agreement will prevail.
   (b)   Questions regarding the interpretation and application of these
policies shall be directed toward the appropriate department head or designee.
(Ord. 97-40.  Passed 4-2-98; Ord. 18-15.  Passed 2-13-18.)
DEFINITIONS
258.020  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (a)   "Active pay status." All hours spent by an employee in actual assigned
work duty, all prescheduled vacation hours, and all pre-scheduled holiday
hours.
   (b)   "Affirmative action plan." An outlined course of action designed to
ensure equal opportunity in Village employment and promotion practices.
   (c)   "Casual time." Time off with pay in lieu of overtime for salaried/
exempt employees. For every hour worked over the exempt employee's normal work
week, that employee will receive equal time off at a future date, which shall
be taken no later than one year from date earned.
   (d)   "Compensatory time." Compensation granted in the form of time off from
regular duties in lieu of additional salary or wages. For every hour worked
over the non-exempt employee's normal work week, that employee will receive
time and a half or double time off (depending on method earned) at a future
date, which shall not extend past the last day of February for police and fire
departments and not past the last day of April for all other departments in the
succeeding year in which the time was earned.
   (e)   "Eligibility list." A list of persons eligible for employment or
promotion, as determined by examination and by provisions of these policies. An
eligibility list is established at the date of original appointment or
promotion and maintained for full-time employees only.
   (f)   "Examinations." The process by which persons are determined to be
eligible for employment or promotion within the Village. The process may
include, but is not limited to, all or any of the following: review of the
candidate's application form, verification of application information, written
and non-written tests, psychological examinations, physical agility tests,
polygraph tests, performance ratings, and oral interview.
   (g)   "Exempt personnel." Personnel in full-time management positions whom
the Council has exempted. Exempt personnel are not eligible to earn paid
overtime or compensatory time but are eligible to earn casual time.
   (h)   "Family." In addition to spouse, the employee's or their spouse's
grandparent, parent, step-parent, child, step-child, grandchild, brother or
sister, as well as any person under the employee's legal guardianship or any
other relative living in the employee's household.
   (i)   "Firefighter." When used in this chapter shall include firefighter/
paramedics.
   (j)   "Full-time employee." Any employee who works at least 37½ hours per
week and is employed 1,950 hours per year is considered a full-time employee.
   (k)   "Holiday equivalent time." Compensation granted in the form of time
off from regular duties in lieu of additional salary or wages for Village
holidays.
   (l)   "Inactive pay status." All hours spent by an employee on sick leave,
authorized leave without pay, and job-related injury leave as approved by the
Ohio Bureau of Workers' Compensation.
   (m)   "Incident." As related to Section 258.120: Total time period which is
greater than four hours, of an employee's regular work day. Example: A person
who works eight hours or 24 hours per day and is off two hours sick leave that
time shall not count as an incident. If that person is off any part over four
hours that time is counted as an incident. Any time off four hours or less and
accumulated that exceeds four hours is counted as one incident. Five
consecutive days with flu is counted as one incident.
   (n)   "Kelly Day." A day off given to firefighters in order to comply with
the Fair Labor Standards Act (Appendix C). Without the Kelly Days, overtime
would have to be paid to each firefighter each time they worked more than 144
hours over a 19 day period.
   (o)   "Management position." A position that customarily and regularly
supervises or directs the work of other employees including the development,
research, implementation, or evaluation of policies, programs and Village
services.
   (p)   "Non-exempt personnel." Employees other than those in full-time
management positions whom Council has exempted. Non-exempt employees are
eligible to earn paid overtime or compensatory time.
   (q)   "Payroll year." Dates worked that align with the first and last
payroll check of the year, as reflected on an individual's W-2.
   (r)   "Part-time employee." Any employee, hired by ordinance, who works less
than 1,950 hours per year is considered a part-time employee. Part-time
employees are considered non-exempt
   (s)   "Probationary employee." The status of any full-time employee during
the first year of employment or any longer period established by ordinance.
   (t)   "Probationary period."
      (1)   The first year of employment for any Village full-time employee or
any longer period of time established by ordinance is a probationary period
during which he/she is required to demonstrate his/her fitness for the job by
actual performance of the duties of the position to which he/she was appointed.
If performance during such a period is unsatisfactory, the employee will be
discharged.
      (2)   The first year or any longer period established by ordinance in
which an employee holds any position to which
         she/he has been promoted is a probationary period during which he/she
is required to demonstrate his/her fitness for the position held by actual
performance of the duties of the position to which he/she was appointed. If
performance is unsatisfactory during such a period, the employee will be
demoted to the position held prior to the promotion by the employee, or if that
position is eliminated, to the next available position that the employee is
capable of holding.
   (u)   "Regular employee." Any full-time employee, hired by ordinance, who
has satisfactorily completed the probationary period is considered a regular
employee.
   (v)   "Seasonal employee." Any person hired by ordinance for a specific
period of employment that generally coincides with a particular season or
seasons of the year - spring, summer, autumn, or winter and works less than
1,950 hours a year, is considered a seasonal employee. Seasonal employees are
considered non-exempt.
   (w)   "Seniority." The length of service as a full- time Village employee
calculated from the date of hire and measured in chronological days. Seniority
will not include any leaves of absence or other breaks in service which Village
policy or Federal or State law do not require to be treated as qualifying for
continuing seniority. Seniority will include all service to the Village in a
full-time capacity, irrespective if interrupted by a break in service, provided
that the break in service was not caused by termination for failure of good
behavior or a voluntary termination occurring while disciplinary proceedings
were pending. Provided, that for the purpose of Police and Fire Department's
service in the command structure of those departments, "seniority" will be
based on the total amount of time spent in the current rank. For personnel
holding the same time in current rank, "seniority" shall be determined by the
total amount of time the employee held the previous rank.
   (x)   "Shift." For all employees, a shift shall be the number of hours in
any one work day as determined by the employer.
   (y)   "Temporary employee." Any person hired under provisions of Section
258.029(f).
      (Ord. 97-40.  Passed 4-2-98; Ord. 05-34.  Passed 8-11-05; Ord. 07-38. 
Passed 7-12-07; Ord. 10-08. Passed 2-11-10.)
